A mintaépítő, csempelerakó sikerjátékok közül ezt gondoljuk az első olyannak, ahol kötetlen a térbeli építkezés, de azóta rátaláltam a Cascadia elődére, amiből ezt fejlesztették, és a HABITATS érdekesebb, mint a Cascadia.
A műfajhoz tartozó játékokat szerintem mindig valahogy egy hajszál választja el attól, hogy magányos pasziánszként éljük meg vagy sem. Ha a feladataink mellett a játék eléri, hogy tudunk és kell az ellenfélre is figyelni, akkor a műfajba tartozó játék sikerült, ha meg nem tudja ezt a játékmenet, akkor a mintaépítő játék meditatív szóló játékká válik és a társas magányt erősíti. Az én értelmezésemben egy ilyen társasjáték nem társasjáték, tehát hiábavaló. Márpedig a Cascadia pont ilyen.

Előnyök és hátrányok:
A tábla nélküli, szabad terjeszkedés miatt itt könnyebb bármit taktikai alapon lerakni. Szabadon építkezhetünk, és ez jó élmény. Emiatt azonban bonyolítani is kellett azon, hogy mi mivel együtt ad pontot, különben nem lenne agytorna. A döntések azonban még így is triviálisak.

Személyesen nekem a Cascadia dizájn is messze van attól, amit vonzónak találok, de ez szubjektív. Viccesnek tartom, hogy míg a társasjátékos közösség az egyik játékot elátkozza, amiért annak témája leválik a mechanikáról, a másik játékot egekbe emeli valami miatt, és már nem is zavarja, hogy ugyanúgy otromba módon leválik róla a téma. Mint itt. Mert az absztrakt mechanikára rakott téma tényleg gyenge a Cascadiában. A havas hegycsúcson megjelenő hal tipikus példája, hogy az egész nagyon erőltetett.

Eredetileg azt gondoltam, na, majd a Calico-t lecserélem ezzel, ha végre megjelenik, mert a Calicoban eléggé erős a szerencse faktor, ami a végén érezhető legjobban, amikor már szűkösnek érződik a zsákhúzásból származó lehetőség. Pedig a Calico elbűvölően szép, és ott pont a határok miatt válik nagyon nehézzé a játék. A végén ennek érezzük a kellemetlenségét is. Húzózsák esetén azonban egy mintaépítő játékban ez a probléma könnyen jelen van, ha nincs valami kiigazítás is, ami ezt orvosolja.

A Cascadia azonban összeütközés és megerőltetés nélküli gondolkodás. És elképesztően terjengős.
Ami leginkább hasonlít hozzá, az talán a Kohaku. Ott sincs kötött építési terület, de ott nem célkártyák nehezítik a csempelerakást, hanem maguk a csempék: a kétféle csempetípuson megjelenő, mást mással párosító minták.

A Cascadia az én szememben egy erősen túlértékelt, gyenge mintaépítő. Népszerűsége a Qwirkle sikerére rímel, amely attól eredeti, hogy a dominót újította meg színekkel és formákkal, miközben nem több, mint csevegés közbeni időtöltés, játéknak alig nevezhető könnyűség, annyira egyszerű és felületes. Kiskorúakkal és öreg családtagokkal persze remek.

A fő baj a Cascadiában súlyosabb, mert a Cascadia nem társasági élmény, és miközben könnyűsége az absztrakt játékok élére emelte, az igazán jó absztrakt játékok alig észrevehetők mellette. Utóbbi persze a tömegízlés látlelete, nem érték kategória. A BGG rangsora az eladást segíti, és pont annyira súlytalan, mint az iMDb-n a legjobb filmek sorrendje, aminek a legjobb filmekhez tényleg semmi köze. :-)

I think this is just about the best casual game for playing with people who do not like board games. That said it is still a bad game, given that there is little to no player interaction.

A lot of people seem to think Wingspan, for example, fits this niche well. I think Cascadia does it infinitely better. Cascadia finds the right balance between allowing for casual, relaxing play and providing an interesting puzzle. Moreover, it has very simple rules that are logical to non-boardgamers and easy to explain.

Like Wingspan, there is a lot of randomness. However, the randomness in Cascadia does not prevent one from making long-term strategic plans. It does however allow one to play more by feel than other mechanically intricate games. Cascadia also shares the broadly appealing nature theme and great artwork that Wingspan has.

My frustration with these types of games lies in the institutionalized activity of a pseudo-peaceful experience. There's hardly any thwarting but in fact, a mutual agreement to share together in the navigating of variable scoring thresholds.

Both designs can learn from Azul which creates dynamic drafting and the ability to assess what your opponents need quickly.

I liked seeing where (I suspect) so many of the tics in the modern take-and-make genre had come from. And this has a few less-imitated tricks up its sleeve, like the tiles requiring a partial, usually not total, commitment to which animals might go there. But in the end for me it still bore the curse of the take-and-make -- players ruined each other's plans frequently, and yet almost never meant to. I would usually rather play a game of totally isolated striving than one which works like that.

Chillax vibes based setting with fun pieces to manipulate. It's nice to sit around and not have to brain too much. Just take tiles and animals, place them together to match some basic scoring opportunities, maybe if you're lucky you'd even get to hate draft, but it's less hate and more friendly jab draft.

But for me this is just a little too chillax, a little too mathed out. The play by play is satisfying enough, but the end result is a bit like staring at a half finished canvas and wondering if it was worth it?

It's hard to justify it sitting on my shelf when I have more fun playing something like Cascadero or Ride the Rails which have similarly light rules loads.

Cascadia should have been right up my alley. I wanted to like it and tried really hard to. The core of the game is there, the looks are there, and so is the challenge of getting the right things in the right places.. but in the end it was one thing that sticks with me... one of the hexes is for a prairie salmon. There isn't even water on the tile and for some reason my brain can only remember that.

Mechanically it is a great game and most people really like it. I even understand why they do.

Very pleasant family weight drafting tile laying point salad that presents an interesting enough puzzle for its playtime. While it presents a lot of potential ways to earn points, the scoring is tight enough that proper placement of the tiles and hate drafting becomes significantly meaningful while still being loose enough to give the game a casual appeal. The game offers enough luck mitigation that you never feel frustrated with your options or mad that your opponent got lucky. That said, the game does still suffer from the same "the perfect combo piece gets revealed for my opponent after whatever I took" issue that many similar games are hurt by.
I still find this one to be the best of the "take & make" type of games, but I'm just cooling on the genre in general.

One of my favorite abstract strategy games for its combination of straightforward gameplay and strategic depth. I appreciate the light interaction between players, being able to draft tiles that would be more favorable to another player, or strategically wipe the slate. I find each game starts out exciting as players work out their scoring avenues, but sort of becomes a drafting slog towards the end. Prefer multiplayer to solo.

A Calico killer made by the very makers of Calico.

This went from a perennial almost-bought, based on the box and description that just came up short, to a favorite and the first game I have rated a 10 here on BGG. That rating has now fallen to a 9, though.

This is the holy grail of games for me: a simple game that is fast, fluid, and full of opportunities for both strategic and tactical plays. While the game is inherently competitive, it is not necessarily loaded with backstabbing and nastiness.

Each player gets a starting tile comprised of three hexagons arranged around a central point. One is a keystone tile (one of the five animal types and one of the five habitat types), and the other two are each two habitat types such that all five appear between the hexagons, and between them all five animal types (two on one and three on the other, including the keystone species from before). These are all of the possible combinations (one each habitat and animal, two habitats and two animals, and two habitats and three animals).

The game comes with 83 tiles, and a game requires 20X+3 tiles, where X is the number of players, so a 3-player game uses 63 tiles. Players put out four tile-animal combinations, and when it is a player's turn, that player takes one pairing, placing the tile and, if possible and desired (almost always) placing the animal. The tile can go anywhere, but larger sections of orthogonally adjacent habitat types score more points. Animals may only be placed on a habitat that has the appropriate animal symbol.

When you play an animal on a keystone tile, you get a pine cone that you can use later to pick a tile from one pairing and an animal from another.

While you score for the habitats in the largest corridors you create, you also score by placing the various species into configurations from randomized cards for each animal type. Between these two forces, the game never repeats.

Setup takes a couple of minutes, and rebooting takes even less time. Scoring takes only a couple of minutes as well, and gameplay is so quick that players can squeeze in a couple of games in less time than many other games they likely own.
Must have !

A perfect game for non-gamers, and gamers alike. One of the most satisyfing, engaging and social personal puzzle games on the market. The interchangebale point cards add some much needed variety and a decent range of complexity levels.

You almost never feel like you are out of options, and the ability to cull animals with nature tokens and when you have over population is exciting everytime for all players around the table. If I could only keep 5 games, Cascadia (along in with it's expansion) would definitely stay, no questions asked
Must have in any starting collection. Equally fun as a cosy game or as puzzly challenge

Best abstract, beautiful and easy to learn tile drafting game. Get the correct tiles and tokens to make the best ecosystem and score the most with your wildlife and habitats. Works perfect solo and with any number of players, one of my all time favorites.
